PT J
AN ZOOR15102011249
DT Article
TI The Subfamily Cytheropterinae Hanai, 1957 (Subphylum Crustacea, Class
   Ostracoda) from the Southern Brazilian Continental Shelf.
AU Feijo Ramos, Maria Ines (mramos@museu-goeldi.br) 
   Coimbra, Joao Carlos
   Whatley, Robin Charles
SO Revue de Micropaleontologie
VL 57
IS 4
PS 141-154
PD Oct 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of the subfamily Cytheropterinae from the southern Brazilian
   continental shelf reveals the presence of four genera and nine species,
   including two newly described (Cytheropteron sudadanticum sp. nov.,
   Loxoreticulatum pulchrum sp. nov.) and two left in open nomenclature
   (Cytheropteron sp. and Kangarina sp.). All of these species are
   restricted to the southern part of the Southwest Atlantic Ocean and do
   not extend beyond the coast of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Three of these
   species (Oculocytheropteron micropunctatum, O. reticulaturn, O.
   macropunctaturn) extend beyond the southern limit of the Brazilian
   Province (36[degree]S), while the others occur inside the limits of the
   Brazilian Province (36[degree]S-22/21[degree]S). The genus Loxoreticulat
   urn, a well-known ostracod taxon from the Antarctic Peninsula, southern
   Argentina and Falkland (=Malvinas) Islands, is herein reported for the
   first time from offshore Brazil. (C) 2014 Elsevier Masson SAS. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Feijo Ramos, Maria Ines; Museu Paraense Emilio Goeldi, Av Perimetral,Cx
   Postal 399,1901, Belem, Para, BR-66077530 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM mramos@museu-goeldi.br
RI Coimbra, Joao Carlos/H-7500-2013
OI Coimbra, Joao Carlos/0000-0002-8980-6531
SC Zoology
SN 0035-1598
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Cytheropterinae [South Atlantic / Brazil, south / Distribution;
   systematics]. 
   Cytheropteron sudadanticum; Loxoreticulatum pulchrum [South Atlantic /
   Brazil / New species]. 
   Loxoreticulatum [South Atlantic / Brazil / New record]. 
   Oculocytheropteron macropunctatum; Oculocytheropteron micropunctatum;
   Oculocytheropteron reticulatum [South Atlantic / Brazil, south / New
   record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Cytheropterinae - Hanai 1957 (Ostracoda). 
   Cytheropteron sudadanticum (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Brazil (marine), P.
   144]. 
   Loxoreticulatum (Ostracoda): [New record]. 
   Loxoreticulatum pulchrum (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Brazil (marine), P. 152].
   
   Oculocytheropteron macropunctatum (Ostracoda): [New record]. 
   Oculocytheropteron micropunctatum (Ostracoda): [New record]. 
   Oculocytheropteron reticulatum (Ostracoda): [New record].

TI A new Fulgoraria (Gastropoda: Volutidae) from Vietnam.
FT Une nouvelle Fulgoraria (Gastropoda: Volutidae) du Vietnam
AU Thach, Nguyen Ngoc (kurodashvietnam@yahoo.com) 
SO Xenophora
SU 5
PS 20-24
PD Oct 2014
PY 2014
LA English; French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of genus Fulgoraria Schumacher, 1817 is described from Nha
   Trang, Central Vietnam and compared to the seven other species of this
   genus inhabiting the South China Sea: Fulgoraria (Fulgoraria) bailorum
   Thach, 2014, Fulgoraria (Fulgoraria) ericarum Doute, 1997, Fulgoraria
   (Fulgoraria) rupestris thachi Bail & Chino, 2009, Fulgoraria
   (Fulgoraria) rupestris rupestris (Gmelin, 1791), Fulgoraria (Fulgoraria)
   humerosa Rehder, 1969, Fulgoraria (Fulgoraria) leviuscula Rehder, 1969,
   Fulgoraria (Fulgoraria) kaoae Bail, 2008.
C1 Thach, Nguyen Ngoc; Ex Res Associate, Oceanog Inst, 267 Thong Nhat St,
   Nha Trang, Vietnam, Vietnam.

DT Article
TI Conus (Gastropoda, Conidae) from offshore French Polynesia: Description
   of dredging from TARASOC expedition, with new records and new species.
AU Rabiller, Michael (michael.rabiller@ville-larochelle.fr) 
   Richard, Georges
SO Xenophora
SU 5
PS 25-49
PD Oct 2014
PY 2014
NT Introduction by Bouchet, P.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This article provides an analysis of Conidae dredged at forty nine
   stations during the TARASOC expedition to inventory of the benthic fauna
   of the more central island groups of French Polynesia. Throughout Tarava
   seamounts, some Tuamotu atolls, and deepwater stations off the Society
   Islands were sampled. A total of 29 cone species were collected. Of
   these, 15 represented range extensions of previously described species
   and three are described as new species in this article. The other 11
   species found did not provide any new distribution records or new
   species."
C1 Rabiller, Michael; Museum Hist Nat La Rochelle, 28 Rue Albert 1er, La
   Rochelle, F-17000, France, France.
EM michael.rabiller@ville-larochelle.fr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0755-8198
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Animals and man; Ecology;
   Distribution within habitat; Zoogeography; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Conus [Expeditions / TARASOC expedition / systematics] [Vertical
   distribution / Bathymetric distribution / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [South
   Pacific / French Polynesia / biology; distribution; faunal list]. 
   Conus aito; Conus paumotu; Conus tarava [South Pacific / French
   Polynesia / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Conus - Linnaeus 1758 (Conoidea). 
   Conus aito (Conoidea): [Sp nov, French Polynesia (marine), P. 37]. 
   Conus paumotu (Conoidea): [Sp nov, French Polynesia (marine), P. 35]. 
   Conus tarava (Conoidea): [Sp nov, French Polynesia (marine), P. 39].

DT Article
TI A new endemic species from French Polynesia: Leporiconus pomareae n. sp,
   (Gastropoda, Conidae).
FT Une nouvelle espece endernique de Polynesie Francaise: Leporiconus
   pomareae n. sp. (Gastropoda, Conidae)
AU Monnier, Eric (eric.monnier@cnam.fr) 
   Limpalaer, Loic
SO Xenophora
SU 5
PS 50-60
PD Oct 2014
PY 2014
LA English; French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Leporiconus pomareae n.sp., a new endemic species of Conidae from French
   Polynesia is described. Up to now, this species was confused with L.
   tenuistriatus (Sowerby II, 1858), which has a different geographical
   range and a distinctive outline. Morphometric measurements and DNA
   analysis prove these two species are separate. The new species is
   compared with Leporiconus relatives: L. glans (Kwass in Bruguiere,
   1792), L. coffeae (Gmelin, 1791), L. granum (Rockel & Fischoder, 1985)
   and also with other species with wich it might be confused
C1 Monnier, Eric; CNAM, 292 Rue St Martin, Paris, F-75003, France, France.
EM eric.monnier@cnam.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0755-8198
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Leporiconus pomareae [South Pacific / French Polynesia / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Leporiconus pomareae (Conoidea): [Sp nov, French Polynesia (marine), P.
   50]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15111069488
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI New data on the endemic Cones (Gastropoda, Conidae) of Angola, with the
   description of new species.
FT Informations sur les cones endemiques d'Angola, et descriptions de
   nouvelles especes.
AU Monteiro, Antonio (a.j.a.monteiro@netcabo.pt) 
   Afonso, Carlos M.L.
   Tenorio, Manuel J.
   Rosado, Jose
   Pirinhas, David
SO Xenophora
SU 5
PS 61-76
PD Oct 2014
PY 2014
LA English; French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recent researches along the South Angolan coast has allowed for a better
   understanding of a number of taxa and populations of endemic cone
   snails, and brought to light some previously undescribed species, three
   of which are described in the present paper: Varioconus inesae sp. nov.,
   Varioconus medvedevi sp. nov. and Varioconus petuchi sp. nov.
   Additionally, a redescription of the taxon Varioconus variegatus
   (Kiener, 1845) is presented and documented with direct field
   observations.
C1 Monteiro, Antonio; Rua Carlos Calisto 3-4 E, Lisbon, P-1400043,
   Portugal, Portugal.
EM a.j.a.monteiro@netcabo.pt
SC Zoology

   Atlantic / Angola / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Varioconus inesae (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Angola (marine), P. 74]. 
   Varioconus medvedevi (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Angola (marine), P. 75]. 
   Varioconus petuchi (Conoidea): [Sp nov, Angola (marine), P. 75].

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016412
DT Article
TI Occurrence of Hirudinea species in a post urban reach of a Patagonian
   mountain stream.
AU Miserendino, M. Laura
   Gullo, Bettina S.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 104
IS 3
PS 308-313
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Temporal (May 2005 to February 2006) and habitat distribution (pools and
   riffles) of Hirudinea species was analyzed at a post urban reach from
   Esquel stream (Chubut province, Patagonia, Argentina). Site was located
   5.7 km downstream a Waste Treatment Plant. Mean values of nutrients:
   ammonia, nitrates and soluble reactive phosphate, as well water
   conductivity, turbidity and total suspended solids indicated physical
   and organic pollution. Leeches assemblage was composed by the
   glossiphonids: Helobdella scutifera Blanchard, 1900, H. michaelseni
   (Blanchard, 1900), H. simplex (Moore, 1911), Helobdella sp., H. hyalina
   Ringuelet, 1942, H. obscura Ringuelet, 1942 and the semiscolecid
   Patagoniobdella variabilis (Blanchard, 1900). From these H. hyalina and
   H. obscura are new records for Chubut province. Helobdella hyalina (810
   ind.m-2) and H. simplex (465 ind. m-2) clearly dominated the assemblage
   at the reach. Only H. simplex displayed a spatial preference being
   significantly more abundant in pools than in riffle habitats (p<0.001).
   Species recruitment occurred mostly at September, December and March
   when juveniles were very abundant. Although several species of
   Helobdella were able to live in the disturbed section of the stream,
   only H. simplex and H. hyalina sustained large populations at the site
   and can be considered as tolerant to organic enrichment. This
   information is valuable to future studies on stream condition assessment
   in mountainous areas in Patagonia, and in other areas in which these
   species are present.
C1 Miserendino, M. Laura; CIEMEP CONICET UNPSJB, LIESA, Sarmiento 849,
   Esquel, Esquel, RA-9200, Argentina, Argentina.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0073-4721
BD Animals and man; Ecology; Population dynamics; Habitat; Freshwater
   habitat; Lotic water; Pollution; Abiotic factors; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Helobdella hyalina; Helobdella obscura [Argentina / Patagonia, Chubut
   province / New record]. 
   Hirudinea [Disturbance by man / Urbanization / ] [Community structure / 
   / ] [Recruitment /  / ] [Stream /  / ] [Pollution / Organic pollution /
   ] [Abiotic factors / Environmental variables / ] [Argentina / Patagonia,
   Chubut province, Esquel stream / ]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Hirudinea
OR Hirudinea (Annelida). 
   Helobdella hyalina (Hirudinea): [New record]. 
   Helobdella obscura (Hirudinea): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15103016412
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species of Andocaeculus (Acari, Caeculidae) from the Pampa biome,
   southern Brazil.
AU Ott, Ana Paula (ana.ott@ufrgs.br) 
   Ott, Ricardo
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 104
IS 3
PS 355-363
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new caeculid species Andocaeculus caioi sp. nov. is described from
   Pampa biome in south Brazil. The species of this family are usually
   large and strong sclerotized mites with robust and spinulose legs I and
   II. Until now records of species for South America were known only from
   Chile and Argentina.
C1 Ott, Ana Paula; Univ Fed Rio Grande Sul, Fac Agron, Av Bento Goncalves
   7712, Porto Alegre, RS, BR-91540000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

AN ZOOR15103016419
DT Article
TI A new species of Leiostracus (Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Orthalicoidea) from
   Espirito Santo, Brazil.
AU Salvador, Rodrigo B. (salvador.rodrigo.b@gmail.com) 
   Cavallari, Daniel C.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 104
IS 3
PS 364-366
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A remarkable new species of pulmonate land snail was found in the
   collection of the Senckenberg Forschungninstitut und Naturmuseum
   Frankfurt (Frankfurt am Main, Germany) and is described here as
   Leiostracus faerie sp. nov. It can be easily identified by its small and
   translucent shell with fine axial light brown bands and its protoconch
   sculpture. It was collected in the Rio Doce ("Doce River") region in
   Espirito Santo, Brazil, an area known for a high diversity and
   endemicity of land snails. This discovery shows how little this fauna is
   known and reinforces the importance of museum collections in the study
   of biodiversity and conservation.
C1 Salvador, Rodrigo B.; Staatl Museum Nat Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1,
   Stuttgart, D-70191, Germany, Germany.
EM salvador.rodrigo.b@gmail.com
RI Cavallari, Daniel C/C-6380-2014; Salvador, Rodrigo
   Brincalepe/F-7524-2012; Cavallari, Daniel/Q-1091-2019
OI Cavallari, Daniel C/0000-0003-3104-6434; Salvador, Rodrigo
   Brincalepe/0000-0002-4238-2276; Cavallari, Daniel/0000-0003-3104-6434
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Leiostracus faerie [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora,
   Orthalicoidea

DT Article
TI On a new genus and species of Hemicytheridae (Ostracoda, Crustacea) from
   the southern Brazilian coast.
AU de Morais, Anderson L.M. (crescermorais@hotmail.com) 
   Coimbra, Joao C.
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 104
IS 3
PS 367-372
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB This study is based on 62 samples of phytal and bottom sediments
   collected along rocky beaches (<=3 m water depth) of the central and
   northern coasts of the state of Santa Catarina
   (26[degree]10'/27[degree]50'S - 48[degree]26'/48[degree]40'W), southern
   Brazil. Living and dead ostracodes distributed among 16 families were
   recovered. In this paper is emphasized one new hemicytherid genus and
   species that is described and richly illustrated: Auricythere
   sublitoralis gen. nov. and sp. nov. Some ecological and zoogeographical
   aspects of this new ostracode are briefly discussed.
C1 de Morais, Anderson L.M.; Univ Fed Rio Grande Sul, Dept Paleontol &
   Estratig, Caixa Postal 15001, Porto Alegre, RS, BR-91501970 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM crescermorais@hotmail.com
RI Coimbra, J. C./H-7500-2013
OI Coimbra, J. C./0000-0002-8980-6531
SC Zoology
SN 0073-4721
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Auricythere sublitoralis [South Atlantic / Brazil / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Auricythere (Ostracoda): [Gen nov, Of tribe Aurilini, Type species
   Auricythere sublitoralis, p. 368]. 
   Auricythere sublitoralis (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Brazil (marine), P. 369].

PT J
AN ZOOR15103016421
DT Article
TI Cerambycidae (Coleoptera) from states of Piaui and Ceara, Brazil: known
   species, new tribe, new species and new records.
FT Cerambycidae (Coleoptera) dos estados do Piaui e Ceara, Brasil: especies
   conhecidas, nova tribo, nova especie e novos registros.
AU Martins, Ubirajara R. (urmsouza@usp.br) 
   Santos-Silva, Antonio
   Galileo, Maria Helena M.
   Limeira-de-Oliveira, Francisco
SO Iheringia Serie Zoologia
VL 104
IS 3
PS 373-384
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new species of Compsibidion Thomson, 1864 is described from Piaui.
   Sydacini, a new tribe of Cerambycinae, is validated. Species of
   Cerambycidae currently recorded for Piaui (118) and for Ceara (126) are
   presented. Twenty-two new records for Piaui and eleven for Ceara are
   reported. Two species are excluded from the fauna of Ceara: Hippopsis
   lemniscata lemniscata (Fabricius, 1801), and Oncideres saga (Dalman,
   1823).
C1 Martins, Ubirajara R.; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42494,

DT Article
TI Revision of the Genus Sangariola Jacobson (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae:
   Galerucinae: Alticini).
AU Lee, Chi-Feng (chifeng@tari.gov.tw) 
SO Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
VL 63
IS 3
PS 188-204
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five species of Sangariola Jacobson are recognized as valid. Sangariola
   hirashimai Kimoto, 1970, Sangariola fortunei (Baly 1888), and Sangariola
   punctatostriata (Motschulsky 1861) are redescribed. Sangariola costata
   Chujo, 1935b is removed from synonymy with S. punctatostriata
   (Motschulsky 1861). A new species, Sangariola yuae sp. nov., is
   described from Taiwan. Charidea nigrosuturalis var. obliterata Pic, 1937
   is proposed as a new synonym of S. fortunei (Baly 1888). Lectotypes are
   designated for Charidea fortunei Baly, 1888, Charidea nigrosuturalis
   Pic, 1937, Galleruca (sic!) punctatostriata Motschulsky, 1861, Galeruca
   (Adimonia) multicostata Jacoby, 1885, and Sangariola costata Chujo,
   1935b.
C1 Lee, Chi-Feng; Taiwan Agr Res Inst, Appl Zool Div, Taichung, Taiwan,
   Taiwan.
EM chifeng@tari.gov.tw
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Sangariola yuae [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Charidea fortunei - Baly 1888 (Chrysomelidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   195]. 
   Charidea nigrosuturalis - Pic 1937 (Chrysomelidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 196]. 
   Galeruca (Adimonia) multicostata - Jacoby 1885 (Chrysomelidae):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 198]. 
   Galleruca punctatostriata - Motschulsky 1861 (Chrysomelidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 198]. 
   Sangariola - Jacobson 1922 (Chrysomelidae): [Revision, P. 188; Key to
   species, P. 190]. 
   Sangariola costata - Chujo 1935 (Chrysomelidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 201; Removal from synonymy, With Sangariola punctatostriata
   (Motschulsky 1861), p. 201]. 
   Sangariola fortunei - (Baly 1888) (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   196; Syn nov, Charidea nigrosuturalis var. obliterata Pic 1937, p. 195].

DT Article
TI A new species of Sicyopus (Gobiidae) from Java and Bali.
AU Keith, Philippe (keith@mnhn.fr) 
   Hadiaty, Renny
   Busson, Frederic
   Hubert, Nicolas
SO Cybium
VL 38
IS 3
PS 173-178
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Sicyopus rubicundus n. sp., a sicydiine goby, is described from
   specimens collected in streams of Java and Bali (Indonesia). It differs
   from other species of this amphidromous genus by a combination of
   characters including a first dorsal fin with five spines in both sexes,
   a second dorsal fin with one spine and nine segmented rays, an anal fin
   with one spine and nine segmented rays, and a distinctive body colour in
   male.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Pelvicachromis taeniatus-group (Perciformes), with
   revalidation of the taxon Pelvicachromis kribensis (Boulenger, 1911) and
   description of a new species.
AU Lamboj, Anton (anton.lamboj@univie.ac.at) 
   Bartel, Daniela
   Dell'Ampio, Emiliano
SO Cybium
VL 38
IS 3
PS 205-222
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Sixty-six specimens of seven populations of the Pelvicachromis
   taeniatus-group are compared and examined, using molecular and
   anatomical-morphological methods as well as coloration patterns.
   Accordingly, the taxon P. taeniatus is restricted to populations from
   Benin and Nigeria. For most populations from Cameroon the old taxon P.
   kribensis is revalidated and specimens from the Wouri River are
   described as a new species, P. drachenfelsi sp. nov. Species diagnosis
   is based on molecular characters and coloration patterns mainly in the
   coloration of the male caudal fin. Pelvicachromis drachenfelsi sp. nov.
   shares a black margin and white to pale bluish submargin in the lower
   half of the male caudal fin with P. taeniatus, a coloration pattern
   absent in P. kribensis, but it differs from P. taeniatus by a white
   margin and a black submargin in the dorsal half of this fin (vs a
   pattern of dots in P. taeniatus). Additionally, female of P. taeniatus
   differ from those of P. drachenfelsi sp. nov. and P. kribensis by two or
   three horizontal dark bars in the caudal fin (vs none in P. drachenfelsi
   sp. nov. and one in most populations of P. kribensis). The populations
   of P. kribensis from the Moliwe River system and the Nyong River system
   potentially represent a new species, but a definitive decision requires
   additional material and study. The molecular phylogeny points to the
   possibility that Pelvicachromis is not monophyletic.
C1 Lamboj, Anton; Dept Integrat Zool, Althanstr 14, Vienna, A-1090,
   Austria, Austria.
EM anton.lamboj@univie.ac.at
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0399-0974
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy;
   Biometrics; General morphology; Colour and luminescence; Genetics;
   Evolution; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Pelvicachromis drachenfelsi [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
   Pelvicachromis taeniatus species group [Biometrics / Morphometrics /
   taxonomic revision] [General morphology /  / ] [Colour / Coloration
   patterns / ] [Molecular genetics / Molecular marker sequences / ]
   [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae
OR Pelvicachromis drachenfelsi (Cichlidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 211]. 
   Pelvicachromis kribensis - (Boulenger 1911) (Cichlidae): [Redescription,
   P. 219; Removal from synonymy, With Pelvicachromis taeniatus (Boulenger
   1901), p. 219]. 
   Pelvicachromis taeniatus - (Boulenger 1901) (Cichlidae): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 216; Redescription, P. 216; Removal from synonymy,
   Pelvicachromis kribensis (Boulenger 1911), p. 219]. 
   Pelvicachromis taeniatus species group (Cichlidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15102010083
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15102010084
DT Article
TI Distocyclus guchereauae a new species of Neotropical electric fish,
   (Gymnotiformes: Sternopygidae), from French Guiana.
AU Meunier, Francois J. (meunier@mnhn.fr) 
   Jegu, Michel
   Keith, Philippe
SO Cybium
VL 38
IS 3
PS 223-230
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Several specimens of a new knife-fish, Distocyclus guchereauae,
   belonging to Sternopygidae (Gymnotiformes), were caught in two
   tributaries (Litany and Tampoc) of Maroni river (French Guiana). This
   species differs from the other Distocyclus by having 13-14 versus 11-15
   precaudal vertebrae, a small number of anal fin rays (184-187 versus
   160-260), a triangular head with a short snout and a terminal mouth, and
   the anus located straight below the eyes.
C1 Meunier, Francois J.; Museum Natl Hist Nat, Dept Milieux & Peuplements
   Aquat, CP 026,43 Rue Cuvier, Paris, F-75231, France, France.
EM meunier@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0399-0974

   region; South America

TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Gymnotiformes, Gymnotidae
OR Distocyclus - Mago-Leccia 1978 (Gymnotidae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 228]. 
   Distocyclus guchereauae (Gymnotidae): [Sp nov, French Guiana, P. 224].

TI Bartschia (Agassitula) peartae, a new species of colubrariid
   (Gastropoda: Colubrariidae) from the tropical western Atlantic.
AU Harasewych, M.G. (Harasewych@si.edu) 
SO Nautilus
VL 128
IS 3
PS 91-96
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new western Atlantic species belonging to the "Metula" group is
   described and assigned to the subgenus Agassitula, which is
   provisionally included in the genus Bartschia. This new species,
   Bartschia (Agassitula) peartae, is larger, thinner, more fusiform, and
   more densely pigmented than other western Atlantic members of the
   "Metula" group.

TI Japanese species of the genus Proutia Tutt, 1899 (Lepidoptera:
   Psychidae).

VL 3869

PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of the genus Proutia are described from Japan based on
   both sexes. Proutia maculatella sp. nov. is distinctive in having
   maculated forewing upperside. Proutia nigra, sp. nov. has unicolorous
   blackish brown forewing upperside and similar to the European species,
   P. betulina, but differs from the latter in the longer processes of the
   male valvae and shorter female antennae.

TI A new genus and two new species, one extant and one fossil, in the
   family Troctopsocidae (Psocodea: 'Psocoptera' : Troctomorpha:
   Amphientometae: Electrentomoidea).
AU Mockford, Edward L. (elmockf@ilstu.edu) 
   Garcia Aldrete, Alfonso N.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 2
PS 159-164
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB We describe a new genus, Troctopsocoides, in the family Troctopsocidae
   with two new species, T. erwini n. sp. (Madre de Dios, Peru) and T.
   gracilis n. sp., a fossil in amber from the Dominican Republic. We
   include a diagnosis of the family Troctopsocidae following a recent
   important change in its status and a key to the known genera of the
   family.

TI Haruchlora maesi, a new emerald moth genus and species from Mesoamerica
   (Lepidoptera, Geometridae, Geometrinae).
AU Viidalepp, Jaan (jaan.viidalepp@emu.ee) 
   Lindt, Aare
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 2
PS 165-170
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new genus and species of Neotropical emerald geometrid moths,
   Haruchlora Viidalepp & Lindt, gen. nov., and Haruchlora maesi Viidalepp
   & Lindt, sp. nov. are described. The new genus differs from all other
   New World Geometrinae genera in having a bifid uncus, in characters of
   the pregenital segments of the male abdomen, and in the male genitalia.

DT Article
TI A new Corononcodes Speiser from the Palaearctic Region, with a key to
   species (Diptera: Acroceridae).
AU Kehlmaier, Christian (kehlmaier@web.de) 
   Gharali, Babak
   Jahromi, Bahareh Majnon
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 2
PS 171-179
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Corononcodes ziegleri spec. nov. is described and illustrated based on
   material from Iran. The species represents the second Palaearctic
   representative of this panopine genus. In addition, C. siculus Bezzi is
   recorded from Fuerteventura (Canary Islands, Spain) for the first time.
   An identification key to the Palaearctic species of Corononcodes is
   presented. Additional faunistic records for the Iranian fauna comprise
   Acrocera orbiculus (Fabricius) and an apparently undescribed species of
   Ogcodes Latreille. DNA-barcodes for all Iranian taxa are provided.

TI A new genus and two new species of Alysiinae (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)
   from Papua New Guinea.
AU Braet, Yves (ybraet_kin@yahoo.fr) 
   Van Achterberg, Cees
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 2
PS 189-197
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of the genus Leptotrema van Achterberg, 1988 and one new
   genus of the Alysiinae from Mt Wilhelm, Madang Province, Papua New
   Guinea are described and illustrated. The distribution of the genus
   Leptotrema is extended to the Australasian region. Three new
   combinations are established Idiasta fulmeki (Fischer, 2010) comb. n.
   (=Microcrasis fulmeki Fischer, 2010), Apiasta postfurcata (Papp, 1966)
   comb. n. (=Microcrasis postfurcata (Papp, 1966)), and Leptotrema.
   bovefemora (Bhat, 1979) comb. nov. (=Aspilota bovefemora Bhat, 1979).
   The status of the genus Apiasta Wharton, 2002 (stat. n.) is reviewed.
   Keys are provided to enable their identification.
C1 Braet, Yves; Inst Royal Sci Nat Belgique, Dept Entomol, Rue Vautier 29,
   Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM ybraet_kin@yahoo.fr
OI BRAET, Yves/0000-0001-7583-0656

PD Sep 30 2014

LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species in the genus Dirphiella MICHENER, 1949 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Mexico (Oaxaca) is described and figured: Dirphiella
   pseudotaylori n. sp. The holotype (ex coll. Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau
   (CFMP)) is deposited in coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP), in coll.
   Museum WITT., Munich (Germany), which later, together with this
   collection, will be included in Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen,
   Munich, Germany. The new species can be easily distinguished from its
   nearest relative, D. taylori (DONAHUE & LEMAIRE, 1975), on external
   features. The preimaginal instars are unknown.

AB Two new taxa in the genus Anisota HUBNER, (1820) (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Mexico are described and figured: A. disjaliscana n.

   suprema EDWARDS, 1884 stat. rev, is removed from synonymy with A.

DT Article
TI 'Candidatus Rickettsia asemboensis' and Wolbachia spp. in
   Ctenocephalides felis and Pulex irritans fleas removed from dogs in
   Ecuador.
AU Oteo, Jose A. (jaoteo@riojasalud.es) 
   Portillo, Aranzazu
   Portero, Francisco
   Zavala-Castro, Jorge
   Venzal, Jose M.
   Labruna, Marcelo B.
SO Parasites & Vectors
VL 7
PS 455
PD Sep 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Background: Flea-borne infections are distributed worldwide. Up to date
   there are no reports about microorganisms associated to fleas in
   Ecuador. Methods: Seventy-one Pulex irritans and 8 Ctenocephalides felis
   fleas were removed from dogs in two Ecuadorian areas (Pastaza and
   Chimborazo Provinces) in December 2012. DNA extracts were tested by
   polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assays targeting universal 16S rRNA, as
   well as screened for the presence of Rickettsia spp. (gltA, htrA, ompB,
   sca4 and ompA genes) and Bartonella spp. (rpoB, gltA and ITS genes).
   Results: Our results showed the presence of 'Candidatus Rickettsia
   asemboensis' (highly similar to R. felis) in C. felis and Wolbachia spp.
   endosimbionts in P. irritans collected from animals in Ecuador. No fleas
   were found to be positive for any Bartonella species or Yersinia pestis.
   Conclusions: Clinicians should be aware of the potential risk of this
   new Candidatus Rickettsia sp. and keep in mind other flea-borne
   infections since these flea species frequently bite humans.
C1 Oteo, Jose A.; Hosp San Pedro Ctr Invest Biomed La Rioja CIBIR, Dept
   Enfermedades Infecciosas, C Piqueras 98, Logrono, La Rioja, 26006,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jaoteo@riojasalud.es
RI Oteo, Jose A./AAB-3134-2020; Labruna, Marcelo B/B-6241-2013
OI Labruna, Marcelo B/0000-0002-9675-3132; Portillo,
   Aranzazu/0000-0002-2055-1825; Oteo, Jose A./0000-0001-7080-6542

PM 25265394
DT Article
TI An Exceptionally Preserved Transitional Lungfish from the Lower Permian
   of Nebraska, USA, and the Origin of Modern Lungfishes.
AU Pardo, Jason D. (jdpardo@ucalgary.ca) 
   Huttenlocker, Adam K.
   Small, Bryan J.
SO PLoS ONE
VL 9
IS 9
PS e108542
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB Complete, exceptionally-preserved skulls of the Permian lungfish
   Persephonichthys chthonica gen. et sp. nov. are described.
   Persephonichthys chthonica is unique among post-Devonian lungfishes in
   preserving portions of the neurocranium, permitting description of the
   braincase of a stem-ceratodontiform for the first time. The completeness
   of P. chthonica permits robust phylogenetic analysis of the
   relationships of the extant lungfish lineage within the Devonian
   lungfish diversification for the first time. New analyses of the
   relationships of this new species within two published matrices using
   both maximum parsimony and Bayesian inference robustly place P.
   chthonica and modern lungfishes within dipterid-grade dipnoans rather
   than within a clade containing Late Devonian 'phaneropleurids' and
   common Late Paleozoic lungfishes such as Sagenodus. Monophyly of
   post-Devonian lungfishes is not supported and the Carboniferous-Permian
   taxon Sagenodus is found to be incidental to the origins of modern
   lungfishes, suggesting widespread convergence in Late Paleozoic
   lungfishes. Morphology of the skull, hyoid arch, and pectoral girdle
   suggests a deviation in feeding mechanics from that of Devonian
   lungfishes towards the more dynamic gape cycle and more effective buccal
   pumping seen in modern lungfishes. Similar anatomy observed previously
   in 'Rhinodipterus' kimberyensis likely represents an intermediate state
   between the strict durophagy observed in most Devonian lungfishes and
   the more dynamic buccal pump seen in Persephonichthys and modern
   lungfishes, rather than adaptation to air-breathing exclusively.
C1 Pardo, Jason D.; Univ Calgary, Dept Biol Sci, 2500 Univ Dr 1 NW,
   Calgary, AB, T2N 1N4, Canada, Canada.
EM jdpardo@ucalgary.ca
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1932-6203
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Dipnoi [Evolution /  / Sifnificance of new fossil taxa]. 
   Persephonichthys [Permian /  / New genus]. 
   Persephonichthys chthonica [Nebraska /  / new species] [Permian /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Sarcopterygii,
   Dipnoi
OR Dipnoi (Sarcopterygii). 
   Persephonichthys (Dipnoi): [Gen nov, Type species Persephonichthys
   chthonica, p. 2, Permian; Fossil]. 
   Persephonichthys chthonica (Dipnoi): [Sp nov, Nebraska, Permian, P. 2;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15104023822
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15101001971
PM 25283894
DT Article
TI Two new skinks (Scincidae: Glaphyromorphus) from rainforest habitats in
   north-eastern Australia.
AU Hoskin, Conrad J. (conrad.hoskin@jcu.edu.au) 
   Couper, Patrick J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 1-16
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Tropical rainforest is largely restricted in Australia to the fairly
   continuous Wet Tropics region and disconnected patches to the north on
   Cape York. The Wet Tropics is relatively well explored and studied,
   whereas the rainforests of Cape York have received less attention due to
   their remoteness. Here we describe two new species of Glaphyromorphus
   skinks from rainforest areas on Cape York. The two new species are most
   similar to each other and to G. fuscicaudis and G. nigricaudis, but both
   are readily diagnosed on numerous traits. Glaphyromorphus othelarrni sp.
   nov. is diagnosed from all similar species by its supralabial count
   (typically 8 vs 7), high number of subdigital lamellae beneath the 4th
   finger (14-15 vs < 14), and its relatively longer limbs. Glaphyromorphus
   nyanchupinta sp. nov. is diagnosed from all similar species by its small
   body size (max SVL = [approximately]54 mm vs > 85 mm) and slender body
   shape, low number of subdigital lamellae beneath the 4th toe (17-20 vs
   generally 20 or more), and head and body pattern. Both species also
   differ from each other and similar congeners in other aspects of body
   shape, scalation and colour pattern. Glaphyromorphus othelarrni sp. nov.
   is restricted to boulder-strewn rainforest of the Melville Range, whilst
   Glaphyromorphus nyanchupinta sp. nov. is known only from upland
   rainforest in the McIlwraith Range. We discuss patterns of rainforest
   vertebrate endemism on Cape York, and the importance of lithorefugia in
   generating these.
C1 Hoskin, Conrad J.; James Cook Univ, Coll Marine & Environm Sci,
   Townsville, Qld, 4811, Australia, Australia.
EM conrad.hoskin@jcu.edu.au
RI Hoskin, Conrad J/A-8407-2012
OI Hoskin, Conrad J/0000-0001-8116-6085
SC Zoology; Forestry
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Habitat; Terrestrial
   habitat; Zoogeography; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia;
   Australia
DE Glaphyromorphus nigricaudis group [Australia / north east / Key to
   species]. 
   Glaphyromorphus nyanchupinta; Glaphyromorphus othelarrni [Queensland / 
   / New species]. 
   Vertebrata [Forest and woodland / Rainforest / ] [Zoogeography /
   Endemism / ] [Queensland / Cape York / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Scincidae
OR Vertebrata (Chordata). 
   Glaphyromorphus nigricaudis group (Scincidae): [Key to species,
   Australia, north east, P. 14]. 
   Glaphyromorphus nyanchupinta (Scincidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 10]. 
   Glaphyromorphus othelarrni (Scincidae): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 3]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15101001971
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15101001972
PM 25283895
DT Article
TI Description of Amplimerlinius uramanatiensis sp n. (Nematoda:
   Merliniidae) and observations on three other species of the genus from
   Iran.
AU Ghaderi, Reza
   Karegar, Akbar (rghsh2009@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 17-32
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of the genus Amplimerlinius is described and illustrated
   from the rhizosphere of Vitis sp. from Kurdistan province in western
   Iran. A. uramanatiensis sp. n. is characterized by having seven to eight
   head annuli up to the end of the outer extension of the cephalic
   framework, 29-31 [mu]m long stylet and cylindrical-clavate tail with a
   thin hyaline region (9-11 [mu]m) and smooth terminus. Furthermore, A.
   paraglobigerus and A. macrurus were identified and intra-specific
   variability of A. globigerus was studied in detail, based on 21
   populations collected from different regions of Iran. A key and
   diagnostic compendium to the species of the genus is provided.
C1 Karegar, Akbar; Shiraz Univ, Fac Agr, Shiraz, Iran, Iran.
EM rghsh2009@gmail.com

DT Article
TI New Palaeogene horntail wasps (Hymenoptera, Siricidae) and a discussion
   of their fossil record.
AU Wedmann, Sonja (sonja.wedmann@senckenberg.de) 
   Pouillon, Jean-Marc
   Nel, Andre
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 33-43
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The phylogenetic placement of siricid hymenopterans and especially the
   relationships among Siricidae are not resolved, and are in need of
   further investigation. The fossil record helps to illuminate the
   evolutionary history of this group. In this paper, Xoanon? eocenicus sp.
   nov. is newly described from the Eocene Fossillagerstatte Grube Messel
   (Germany). Although several characters of the wing venation of this
   fossil are similar to the extant genus Xoanon, there remain some doubts
   concerning the generic placement. A newly found fossil is attributed to
   Urocerus ligniticus (Piton, 1940) from the Paloecene Fossillagerstatte
   Menat (France) and provides more morphological information on this
   species. An overview of the fossil record of Siricidae in the strict
   sense is given and the state of knowledge on the different fossils is
   reviewed.
C1 Wedmann, Sonja; Senckenberg Forschungsinst & Nat Museum, Forschungsstn
   Grube Messel, Markstr 35, Messel, D-64409, Germany, Germany.
EM sonja.wedmann@senckenberg.de
OI Wedmann, Sonja/0000-0002-9778-4125

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Siricidae [Geological time periods /  / Overview; fossil record]. 
   Urocerus ligniticus [France / Puy-de-Dome, Menat / new record;
   systematics] [Palaeocene /  / ]. 
   Xoanon? eocenicus [Germany /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Siricidae

DT Article
TI A new species of Opecarcinus Kropp & Manning, 1987 (Crustacea:
   Brachyura: Cryptochiridae) associated with the stony corals Pavona
   clavus (Dana, 1846) and P. bipartita Nemenzo, 1980 (Scleractinia:
   Agariciidae).
AU Van Der Meij, Sancia E.T. (Sancia.vanderMeij@naturalis.nl) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 44-52
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new species of Opecarcinus Kropp & Manning, 1987, is described from
   Indonesia and Malaysia. Opecarcinus cathyae sp. nov. is associated with
   the scleractinian corals Pavona clavus (Dana, 1846) and P. bipartita
   Nemenzo, 1980, inhabiting crescent-shaped cavities or tunnels on the
   coral surface. The new species is the ninth assigned to the genus. It
   can be separated from congeners by the anterolateral orientation of the
   cornea, the carapace with shallow transverse depressions, lacking
   longitudinal depressions, and the smooth dorsal margin of the fifth
   female pereiopod carpus. The distinctive colour pattern can be used as a
   diagnostic character in live specimens.
C1 Van Der Meij, Sancia E.T.; Naturalis Biodivers Ctr, Dept Marine Zool,
   Darwinweg 2, Leiden, NL-2333 CR, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM Sancia.vanderMeij@naturalis.nl
RI van der Meij, Sancia E.T./F-5513-2010
OI van der Meij, Sancia E.T./0000-0002-3759-8945
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean

   associate species] [ / Pavona clavus (Cnidaria) / ] [ /  / ] [North
   Pacific / Malaysia / New species; cnidarian associate] [South Pacific /
   Indonesia / ]. 
   Pavona bipartita [Associations / Opecarcinus cathyae (Crustacea) / New
   associate species] [South Pacific / Indonesia / New associated
   crustacean species]. 
   Pavona clavus [Associations / Opecarcinus cathyae (Crustacea) / New
   associate species] [ /  / ] [North Pacific / Malaysia / New associated
   crustacean species] [South Pacific / Indonesia / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Coelenterates; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia,
   Scleractinia
OR Opecarcinus cathyae (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Malaysia (marine), Associated
   with Pavona clavus (Cnidaria), p. 45]. 
   Pavona bipartita (Scleractinia). 
   Pavona clavus (Scleractinia).

TI Sirindhornia Pinkaew and Muadsub (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae), a new
   enarmoniine genus from Thailand.
AU Muadsub, Sopita
   Pinkaew, Nantasak (sun_svbee@hotmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 53-63
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new enarmoniine genus, Sirindhornia, n. gen., is described based on
   the type species, Sirindhornia pulchella, n. sp., and three additional
   new species: Sirindhornia chaipattana, n. sp., Sirindhornia curvicosta,
   n. sp., and Sirindhornia bifida, n. sp., all from Thailand. A fifth
   species represented only by a single female is morphologically
   characterized but not formally described. Sirindhornia is most closely
   related to Anthozela Meyrick and Irianassa Meyrick but is easily
   distinguished by unique appendages of the tegumen and a conspicuous
   henion in the male genitalia.
C1 Pinkaew, Nantasak; Kasetsart Univ, Fac Agr Kamphaengsaen, Kamphaengsaen
   Campus, Nakhon Pathom, 73140, Thailand, Thailand.

   Eurasia; Asia

   Enarmoniini, Type species Sirindhornia pulchella, p. 54].

DT Article
TI Cyrtodactylus saiyok sp nov., a new dry evergreen forest-dwelling
   Bent-toed Gecko (Squamata: Gekkonidae) from Kanchanaburi Province,
   western Thailand.
AU Panitvong, Nonn
   Sumontha, Montri
   Tunprasert, Jitthep
   Pauwels, Olivier S.G. (npanitvong@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 64-74
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB We describe Cyrtodactylus saiyok sp. nov. from a dry evergreen forest on
   a limestone hill in Khao Krajae, Sai Yok District, Kanchanaburi
   Province, western Thailand. It is characterized by a maximal known SVL
   of 61.0 mm; 18-19 longitudinal rows of dorsal tubercles; 23 or 24
   ventral scale rows between ventrolateral skin folds; a continuous series
   of enlarged femoro-precloacal scales, including 5 pore-bearing
   precloacal scales (males); no precloacal groove or depression;
   transversely enlarged subcaudal scales; a complete black nuchal loop; a
   W-shaped band above shoulders and 3-5 irregular, medially interrupted or
   not, black dorsal bands between limb insertions. Cyrtodactylus saiyok
   sp. nov. is the sixth reptile species that is possibly endemic to Sai
   Yok District.
C1 Pauwels, Olivier S.G.; Inst Royal Sci Nat Belgique, Dept Vertebres
   Recents, Rue Vautier 29, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium, Belgium.
EM npanitvong@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyrtodactylus saiyok [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus saiyok (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 65].

DT Article
TI Reinstatement of Distantasca Dworakowska (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae:
   Typhlocybinae: Empoascini) as a valid genus with new species and new
   combinations.
AU Liu, Yang
   Fletcher, Murray J.
   Zhang, Ya-Lin (yalinzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3869
IS 1
PS 90-96
PD Sep 29 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Distantasca Dworakowska originally established as a genus but more
   recently has been treated as a subgenus of Empoasca Walsh. Here we
   reinstate Distantasca as a valid genus and provide a revised diagnosis.
   New combinations created are Distantasca atika (Dworakowska), n. comb.,
   Distantasca barawa (Dworakowska), n. comb., Distantasca bulbosa
   (Dworakowska), n. comb., Distantasca latava (Dworakowska), n. comb.,
   Distantasca latibasis (Zhang & Liu), n. comb., Distantasca
   paraterminalis (Qin & Zhang), n. comb., Distantasca riora (Dworakowska),
   n. comb., Distantasca rokasa (Dworakowska), n. comb., Distantasca
   serratipenis (Qin & Zhang), n. comb., Distantasca tiaca (Dworakowska),
   n. comb., Distantasca tna (Dworakowska), n. comb., Distantasca
   tuberculata (Zhang & Liu), n. comb., all from Empoasca (Distantasca).
   Distantasca terminalis (Distant) and D. faciata Dworakowska are
   reinstated from Empoasca (Distantasca). Two new species, Distantasca
   longihamatilis Zhang & Liu and Distantasca ricina Zhang & Liu spp. nov.
   are described and illustrated. Empoasca (Empoasca) smithi Fletcher &
   Donaldson, 1992 is transferred into the genus as Distantasca smithi
   (Fletcher & Donaldson).
C1 Zhang, Ya-Lin; Northwest A & F Univ, Entomol Museum, Yangling, Shaanxi
   Province, 712100, China, China.
EM yalinzh@nwsuaf.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   zones /  / ].

   Distantasca ricina [Hainan /  / New species] [Yunnan /  / ].

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Sinoennea Kobelt from China (Pulmonata,
   Styommatophora, Streptaxidae).
AU Fan, Biao
   Tian, Ming
   Chen, Yuanxiao (cyx616@hotmail.com) 
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 33
IS 5
PS 694-696
PD September 28 2014
PY 2014
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 2
AB The genus Sinoennea Kobelt belongs to the family Streptaxidae. Its
   distribution range was limited in East Asia and South Asia. The current
   paper reported a new species of genus Sinoennea Kobelt fromChina:
   Sinoennea manyunensis sp. nov. The samples were collected from Manyun
   town, Lushui county, (25[degree]09[minute]N,98[degree]08[minute]E),
   Yunnan province, China in 2011. The type specimens were deposited in the
   Department of Cell Biology and Genetics, Kunming Medical University.
   Sinoennea manyunensis sp. nov. (Plate. 1~4) Holotype : alt.6.20 mm,
   diam.3.30 mm; alt of aperture2.00 mm, diam. of aperture1.00 mm;
   collected from Manyun town, Lushui county,
   (25[degree]09[minute]N,98[degree]08[minute]E), Yunnan province, China,
   Aug 6th 2011. Paratypes: 5 adult shells specimens, alt. 6.16~6.25
   mmdiam. 2.43~3.15~3.35 mm; alt of aperture 1.90~2.10 mm, diam. of
   aperture. 0.94~1.15 mm, collected from Manyun town, Lushui county
   (25[degree]09[minute]N,98[degree]08[minute]E), Yunnan province, China,
   Aug 6th 2011. Etymology: The name of the new species is based on the
   place (Manyun town, Lushui founty) that the specimens were collected.
   Shell small, thick, solid, smooth, lustrous, cylindrical. Whorls 7 1/2,
   moderately convex with high spiral part. Shells light yellow or
   yellow-brownish in colour, and with some curve vertically 68 rib-strias,
   but the embryonic and second without rib-stria, smooth. Apex blunt and
   short, with deep suture. Aperture small, ear-shaped. The peristome is
   thick, expanded and reflexed, on aperture dorsal lateral with neck,
   bell-shaped. The inner lip is close to the body whorl, with thick
   callus. The columellar lip slightly over umbilicus, and perfectly
   straight. There is a big flake-form angular lamellae at the upper right
   lip. There is a big nipple-flake-form teeth below. The umbilicus is
   narrow, slit like. Habitat environment: It generally lives in the dark
   wet humus limestone mountainous and hilly regions, geomorphic
   environment of Karst, cliff with moss and lichen or among the stones.
   The new species is remarkably similar to Sinoennea fuzhouensis Zhou,
   Chen and Guo, 2006, but differs from the latter by the shells with 7 1/2
   whorls, (alt.5.17 mm, diam.2.57 mm;alt of aperture1.86 mm, diam. of
   aperture1.48 mm.) in the small size, with a big flake-form angular
   lamellae at inner lip, with two nipple-flake-form teeth in right lip.
   The upper one is bigger than the below one, axial margin does not cover
   the umbilicus which is wide and deep.
C1 Chen, Yuanxiao; Department of Cell Biology and Medical Genetics, Kunming
   Medical University, Kunming 650500, China, China.
EM cyx616@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Sinoennea manyunensis [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora,
   Streptaxoidea
OR Sinoennea manyunensis (Streptaxoidea): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 695].

DT Article
TI Two New Species of Genus Scionecra (Phasmida: Diapheromeridae:
   Necrosciinae) from China and Vietnam.
AU Ho, Waichun George (georgehwc@hotmail.com) 
   Zhang, Binglan
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 33
IS 5
PS 698-699
PD September 28 2014
PY 2014
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species, Scionecra huai Ho, sp. nov. and Scionecra maculata Ho,
   sp. nov., of the genus Scionecra from ChinaandVietnam, were presented in
   this study. The type specimens of the new species were deposited in
   theMuseumofBiology,SunYat-SenUniversity,Guangzhou. 1. Scionecra huai Ho,
   sp. nov. (Figs. 1) This new species is similar to Scionecra microptera
   (Redtenbacher, 1908), but differs in elongate posterolateral angles of
   ninth abdominal tergum and short cerci which is shorter than anal
   segment. 2. Scionecra maculata Ho, sp. nov. (Figs. 2) This new species
   is similar to Scionecra microptera (Redtenbacher, 1908), but differs in
   elongate posterolateral angles of ninth abdominal tergum and broadly
   emarginated hind margin of anal segment.
C1 Ho, Waichun George; Hong Kong Entomological Society, Hong Kong, China,
   China.
EM georgehwc@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Scionecra huai [China /  / New species]. 
   Scionecra maculata [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Phasmida
OR Scionecra huai - Ho 2014 (Phasmida): [Sp nov, China, P. 698]. 
   Scionecra maculata - Ho 2014 (Phasmida): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 699].

TI Overcoming the fragility - X-ray computed micro-tomography elucidates
   brachiopod endoskeletons.
AU Seidel, Ronald (ronald.seidel@mpikg.mpg.de) 
   Lueter, Carsten
SO Frontiers in Zoology
VL 11
PS 1-15
PD Sep 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Introduction: The calcareous shells of brachiopods offer a wealth of
   informative characters for taxonomic and phylogenetic investigations. In
   particular scanning electron microscopy (SEM) has been used for decades
   to visualise internal structures of the shell. However, to produce
   informative SEM data, brachiopod shells need to be opened after chemical
   removal of the soft tissue. This preparation occasionally damages the
   shell. Additionally, skeletal elements of taxonomic/systematic interest
   such as calcareous spicules which are loosely embedded in the lophophore
   and mantle connective tissue become disintegrated during the preparation
   process. Results: Using a nondestructive micro-computed tomography
   ([mu]CT) approach, the entire fragile endoskeleton of brachiopods is
   documented for the first time. New insights on the structure and
   position of tissue-bound skeletal elements (spicules) are given as add
   ons to existing descriptions of brachiopod shell anatomy, thereby
   enhancing the quality and quantity of informative characters needed for
   both taxonomic and phylogenetic studies. Here, we present five modern,
   articulated brachiopods (Rectocalathis schemmgregoryi n. gen., n. sp.,
   Eucalathis sp., Gryphus vitreus, Liothyrella neozelanica and
   Terebratulina retusa) that were X-rayed using a Phoenix Nanotom XS 180
   NF. We provide links to download 3D models of these species, and
   additional five species with spicules can be accessed in the
   Supplemental Material. In total, 17 brachiopod genera covering all
   modern articulated subgroups and 2 inarticulated genera were X-rayed for
   morphological analysis. Rectocalathis schemmgregoryi n. gen., n. sp. is
   fully described. Conclusion: Micro-CT is an excellent non-destructive
   tool for investigating calcified structures in the exo- and
   endoskeletons of brachiopods. With high quality images and interactive
   3D models, this study provides a comprehensive description of the
   profound differences in shell anatomy, facilitates the detection of new
   delicate morphological characters of the endoskeleton and gives new
   insights into the body plan of modern brachiopods.
C1 Seidel, Ronald; Max Planck Inst Colloids & Interfaces, Potsdam Golm Sci
   Pk,Muhlenberg 1OT Golm, Potsdam, D-14476, Germany, Germany.
EM ronald.seidel@mpikg.mpg.de
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1742-9994
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Shell morphology; Evolution; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean;
   Geological time periods
DE Brachiopoda [Shell biometrics / Morphometrics / taxonomic implications]
   [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Rectocalathis schemmgregoryi [North Pacific /  / New species].

TI Description of four new species of Proagoderus Lansberge, 1883, from

AB Four new species of the genus Proagoderus from Zambia, Malawi and
   Mozambique are described and illustrated : Proagoderus edithae n. sp.,

   Proagoderus camiadei n. sp.

DT Article
TI INDIRANA CHIRAVASI, A NEW SPECIES OF LEAPING FROG (ANURA: RANIXALIDAE)
   FROM WESTERN GHATS OF INDIA.
AU Padhye, Anand D. (anand.padhye@mesagc.org) 
   Modak, Nikhil
   Dahanukar, Neelesh
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 6
IS 10
PS 6293-6312
PD Sep 26 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Indirana chiravasi, a new species of leaping frog is described from the
   northern Western Ghats around Amboli, Sindhudurg District, Maharashtra,
   India. It differs from all its congeners based on a combination of
   characters including presence of median single internal vocal sac, head
   longer than wide, distinct canthus rostralis, tympanum 2/3rd to 3/4th
   the diameter of eye, vomerine teeth in two oblique series at the
   posterior border of choanae, long midventral lingual papilla, first
   finger longer than or equal to second, presence of double outer palmer
   tubercle, thin and elongated inner metatarsal tubercle, absence of outer
   metatarsal tubercle, webbing moderate, dorsal skin with glandular folds
   but without warts, ventral skin smooth without mottling and palms and
   soles dark brown. Molecular analysis based on mitochondrial 12S and 16S
   genes and nuclear rhodopsin and rag1 genes suggests that the species is
   genetically distinct from other species for which genetic data is
   available. Preliminary observations on the development of the species
   are also provided. We also provide genetic data and images for Indirana
   gundia collected from the type locality.
C1 Padhye, Anand D.; Abasaheb Garware Coll, Dept Zool, Karve Rd, Pune,
   Maharashtra, 411004, India, India.
EM anand.padhye@mesagc.org
RI Dahanukar, Neelesh/B-2816-2012
OI Dahanukar, Neelesh/0000-0001-7162-9023; Padhye,
   Anand/0000-0002-5971-4759; Modak, Nikhil/0000-0003-3303-7056
SC Zoology
SN 0974-7893; 0974-7907

AN ZOOR15106037074
DT Article
TI Comparative morphology of the endophallic structures of the genus Laius
   (Coleoptera, Melyridae), with the descriptions of three new species.
AU Yoshitomi, Hiroyuki (hymushi@agr.ehime-u.ac.jp) 
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 97
PS 1-29
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The endophallic structure of the genus Laius is studied and discussed
   based on the examination of 19 species from Asia to the Indian Ocean.
   The structure contains two primary sclerites (named gonoporal piece and
   ligula), a secondary sclerite on the basal part of the gonoporal piece
   (named additional sclerite) in some species, and a membranous basal area
   closely covered with many spines (named spinous area). Five species
   groups are recognized based on the morphology of the endophallic
   sclerites. The sympatric species have different body sizes and quite
   distinguishable endophallic sclerites (= different species group), while
   the allopatric species have overlapping body sizes and similar
   endophallic sclerites (= same species group). Three new species are
   described and six previously known species are redescribed with
   endophallic sclerites, and the descriptions of endophallic sclerites of
   the remaining ten species are added. The larva of Laius rodriguesensis
   sp. nov. is also described. The genus Nossibeus Evers, 1994 is
   synonymised with Laius Guerin-Meneville, 1830.
C1 Yoshitomi, Hiroyuki; Ehime Univ Museum, Bunkyo 3, Matsuyama, Ehime,

DT Article
TI Reclassification of Oligodon ningshaanensis Yuan, 1983 (Ophidia:
   Colubridae) into a New Genus, Stichophanes gen. nov with Description on
   Its Malacophagous Behavior.
AU Wang, Xiaohe
   Messenger, Kevin
   Zhao, Ermi (zhaoermi@cib.ac.cn) 
   Zhu, Chaodong
SO Asian Herpetological Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 137-149
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The complete mitochondrial cytb gene and the partial nuclear c-mos gene
   of Oligodon ningshaanensis Yuan, 1983 were sequenced and used for
   reconstructing the phylogenetic relationship of this taxon amongst
   alethinophidian snakes. Its strong affinity to the New World subfamily
   Dipsadinae and the Old World species Thermophis baileyi was inferred.
   Hemipenial morphology found by authors conflicts with the original
   description and its similarity with those of the dipsadid snakes is in
   accordance with our molecular results. Feeding tests show that O.
   ningshaanensis is a malacophagous predator, which is another matchless
   character for this species. This behavior is described and compared with
   other known slug- and snail-feeding snakes. The discovery of the
   particular position of our subject indicates that erecting a new genus
   is necessary accommodate this unique species.
C1 Zhao, Ermi; Chinese Acad Sci, Chengdu Inst Biol, Chengdu, Sichuan,
   China, China.
EM zhaoermi@cib.ac.cn
RI Messenger, Kevin/J-8322-2019; ZHU, Chao-Dong/E-5961-2011
OI Messenger, Kevin/0000-0002-5363-7393; ZHU, Chao-Dong/0000-0002-9347-3178

DT Article
TI Description of a New Species of the Genus Brachytarsophrys Tian and Hu,
   1983 (Amphibia: Anura: Megophryidae) from Southern China Based on
   Molecular and Morphological Data.
AU Zhao, Jian
   Yang, Jianhuan
   Chen, Guoling
   Chen, Chunquan
   Wang, Yingyong (wangyy@mail.sysu.edu.cn) 
SO Asian Herpetological Research
VL 5
IS 3
PS 150-160
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species, Brachytarsophrys popei sp. nov., is described based on a
   series of specimens collected from Mount Jinggang, Jiangxi Province,
   Taoyuandong Nature Reserve, Hunan Province and Nanling Nature Reserve,
   Guangdong Province, China. The new species can be easily distinguished
   from other known congeners by morphology, morphometrics and molecular
   data of the mitochondrial 16S rRNA gene. It is characterized by its
   relatively small size with 86.2 mm in snout-vent length in adult female
   and 70.7 mm-83.5 mm in males; vomerine teeth bearing on two markedly
   elevated ridges, which projecting behind far beyond the posterior level
   of the choanae, widely separated by a distance nearly 1.5 times length
   of one; margin of tongue deeply notched behind; toes about one-third to
   two-thirds webbed in males, at most one-third webbed in female; the webs
   extending as a wide fringes along either side of toes; upper eyelid with
   tubercles, one of which is enlarged and becoming a remarkably prominent,
   bluntly conical light-yellow horn; black tiny nuptial spines on the
   dorsal surface of the first finger and second finger base, single vocal
   sac in males; gravid females bear pure yellowish oocytes; tadpoles with
   a transverse white stripe on ventral surface and two longitudinal white
   stripes along the sides of body. The new species represents the fifth
   known Brachytarsophrys species.
C1 Wang, Yingyong; Sun Yat Sen Univ, Guangzhou, Guangdong, 510275, China,
   China.
EM wangyy@mail.sysu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Brachytarsophrys popei [Guangdong /  / New species] [Hunan /  / ]
   [Jiangxi /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Pelobatidae
OR Brachytarsophrys popei - Wang, Yang & Zhao 2014 (Pelobatidae): [Sp nov,
   Hunan, P. 154].

DT Article
TI A preliminary study on grasshoppers in Nonggang Nature Reserve of
   Guangxi, China.
AU Wei Tao
   Nong Chong-Gang
   Huang Jian-Hua (924293764@qq.com) 
SO Huanjing Kunchong Xuebao
VL 36
IS 5
PS 843-852
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of systematic inverstigation, a total of 143 species of
   grasshoppers (including 1family 3 genera and 5 species in
   Pyrgomorphoidea, 4 families 42 genera and 69 species in Acridoidea, 7
   families 21 genera 68 species in Tetrigoidea and 1 family 1 genera 1
   species in Eumastacoidea) were recorded from Nonggang Nature Reserve, of
   which 2 species were recorded for the first time from Guangxi, and 1
   genus and 25 species were reported as new records of Nonggang Nature
   Reserve. Two new nomenclatures were proposed, i. e. Tetrix neozhengi
   Huang Nom. nov. and Euparatettix zhengi Huang Nom. nov. were proposed as
   replacement names of Tetrix longzhouensis Zheng, 2004 and Euparatettix
   longipennis (Zheng et Jiang, 2000), respectively. Species component
   analysis showed that Catantopidae, Tetrigidae, Scelimenidae and
   Metrodoridae represent the the dominant groups of grasshoppers in
   Nonggang and typical members in tropical and subtropical regions.
C1 Huang Jian-Hua; Guangxi Normal Univ, Guangxi Key Lab Rare & Endangered
   Anim Ecol, Guilin, Guangxi, 541004, China, China.
EM 924293764@qq.com

   region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   longzhouensis Zheng 2004, p. 848].

DT Article
TI New Patagonian species of Liolaemus (Iguania: Liolaemidae) and novelty
   in the lepidosis of the southernmost lizard of the world: Liolaemus
   magellanicus.
AU Simon Abdala, Cristian
   Esteban Procopio, Diego
   Anibal Stellatelli, Oscar
   Travaini, Alejandro
   Rodriguez, Alejandro
   Ruiz Monachesi, Mario Ricardo (samiryjazmin@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 526-542
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 1
U2 6
AB We describe a new species within the genus Liolaemus from southeast
   Argentine Patagonia. This new taxon, Liolaemus yatel sp. nov., presents
   anatomical traits shared with the Liolaemus lineomaculatus section
   within the Liolaemus lineomaculatus group, especially the absence of
   precloacal pores in both sexes. However, Liolaemus yatel sp. nov. does
   not exhibit trifid dorsal scales, which is a diagnostic character of the
   L. lineomaculatus group. Moreover, this new species differs from other
   taxa of the L. lineomaculatus group in that dorsal and nuchal scales
   either completely lack keels or are slightly keeled. We also report, for
   the first time, the presence of trifid scales in Liolaemus magellanicus,
   another species included in the L. lineomaculatus section but
   constituting an independent lineage regarding the L. lineomaculatus
   group. The phenotypic traits of L. yatel sp. nov. and the presence of
   trifid scales in L. magellanicus provide additional information for the
   study of evolutionary relationships among the species of the L.
   lineomaculatus section, especially the establishment of their diagnostic
   character states.
C1 Ruiz Monachesi, Mario Ricardo; UNT, Fdn Miguel Lillo, Miguel Lillo 205,
   Tucuman, Argentina, Argentina.
EM samiryjazmin@gmail.com
RI Rodriguez, Alejandro/E-7709-2011
OI Rodriguez, Alejandro/0000-0001-9367-3420; Travaini,
   Alejandro/0000-0002-2694-6617
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Integument; Integumentary
   derivatives; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Liolaemus magellanicus [Scales / Trifid scales / First report]. 
   Liolaemus magellanicus group [Evolution /  / Systematics] [Argentina / 
   / distribution]. 
   Liolaemus yatel [Argentina /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae

   Liolaemus magellanicus group (Iguanidae). 
   Liolaemus yatel (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, P. 528].

DT Article
TI A New Species of Lathromeroidea Girault (Hymenoptera: Trichogrammatidae)
   from China.
AU Liu Sizhu (lichen-gde0608@sina.com) 
   Li Chengde
SO Journal of Northeast Forestry University
VL 42
IS 9
PS 177-179
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Family Trichogrammatidae, Lathromeroidea latiscapa Liu
   et Li, sp. nov., collected from Hei-longjiang Province, was reported.
   The characters of adult female were described in detail and a key to all
   the known Chinese species of the genus was provided with the
   characteristic photos and distributional data. The new species closely
   resembles with Korean species L. multidenta Hu, Lin & Kim, 2008, but can
   be separated with the latter by the shape and relative dimensions of
   antennal scape, and the sculpture of midlobe of mesoscutum.

DT Article
TI Brain structure resolves the segmental affinity of anomalocaridid
   appendages.
AU Cong, Peiyun
   Ma, Xiaoya
   Hou, Xianguang (xghou@ynu.edu.cn) 
   Edgecombe, Gregory D.
   Strausfeld, Nicholas J.
SO Nature (London)
VL 513
IS 7519
PS 538-542
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
NT Supplementary information available online.
LA English
U1 1
U2 56
AB Despite being among the most celebrated taxa from Cambrian biotas,
   anomalocaridids (order Radiodonta) have provoked intense debate about
   their affinities within the moulting-animal clade that includes
   Arthropoda. Current alternatives identify anomalocaridids as either
   stem-group euarthropods1-3, crown-group euarthropods near the ancestry
   of chelicerates4, or a segmented ecdysozoan lineage with convergent
   similarity to arthropods in appendage construction5. Determining
   unambiguous affinities has been impeded by uncertainties about the
   segmental affiliation of anomalocaridid frontal appendages. These
   structures are variably homologized with jointed appendages of the
   second (deutocerebral) head segment, including antennae and 'great
   appendages' of Cambrian arthropods, or with the paired antenniform
   frontal appendages of living Onychophora and some Cambrian lobopodians.
   Here we describe Lyrarapax unguis-pinus, a new anomalocaridid from the
   early Cambrian Chengjiang biota, southwest China, nearly complete
   specimens of which preserve traces of muscles, digestive tract and
   brain. The traces of brain provide the first direct evidence for the
   segmental composition of the anomalocaridid head and its appendicular
   organization. Carbon-rich areas in the head resolve paired
   pre-protocerebral ganglia at the origin of paired frontal appendages.
   The ganglia connect to areas indicative of a bilateral pre-oral brain
   that receives projections from the eyestalk neuropils and compound
   retina. The dorsal, segmented brain of L. unguispinus reinforces an
   alliance between anomalocaridids and arthropods rather than
   cycloneuralians. Correspondences in brain organization between
   anomalocaridids and Onychophora resolve pre-protocerebral ganglia,
   associated with pre-ocular frontal appendages, as characters of the last
   common ancestor of euarthropods and onychophorans. A position of
   Radiodonta on the euarthropod stem-lineage implies the transformation of
   frontal appendages to another structure in crown-group euarthropods,
   with gene expression and neuroanatomy providing strong evidence that the
   paired, pre-oral labrum is the remnant of paired frontal appendages1.
C1 Hou, Xianguang; Yunnan Univ, Yunnan Key Lab Palaeobiol, Kunming, 650091,
   China, China.
EM xghou@ynu.edu.cn
RI Cong, Pei-yun/D-2537-2009
OI Cong, Pei-yun/0000-0001-9910-6478; Edgecombe,
   Gregory/0000-0002-9591-8011
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Neurosciences &Neurology
SN 0028-0836
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Nervous system;
   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time
   periods; Palaeozoic

DT Article
TI New olenelloid trilobites from the Northwest Territories, Canada.
AU Gapp, I. Wesley (wes.gapp@gmail.com) 
   Lieberman, Bruce S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 479-498
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The Olenelloidea are a superfamily of early Cambrian trilobites, which
   have been the subject of several phylogenetic analyses and also used to
   address macroevolutionary questions regarding the nature and timing of
   the Cambrian radiation. The Sekwi Formation of the Mackenzie Mountains,
   Northwest Territories, Canada, has yielded numerous species from this
   clade, and here we present new information that expands on the diversity
   known from this biogeographically and biostratigraphically important
   region. In particular, we describe seven new species, (Olenellus
   baileyi, Mesonacis wileyi, Elliptocephala jaredi, Holmiella taurus, H.
   domackae, Mummaspis delgadoae, and Bristolia colberti). Also recovered
   are specimens of Elliptocephala logani, specimens that shared affinities
   with Olenellus clarki, O. getzi, O. fowleri, and Frizolenellus hanseni,
   and one partial specimen, which appears to be a new species of
   Bolbolenellus.

   USA, USA.
EM wes.gapp@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Three new species of Simulium (Nevermannia) (Diptera: Simuliidae) from
   Vietnam.
AU Takaoka, Hiroyuki (takaoka@oita-u.ac.jp) 
   Sofian-Azirun, Mohd
   Ya'cob, Zubaidah
   Chen, Chee Dhang
   Lau, Koon Weng
   Xuan Da Pham
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 555-571
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species of black flies, Simulium (Nevermannia) langbiangense,
   S. (N.) phami, and S. (N.) bachmaense, are described on the basis of
   females, males, pupae and larvae collected in Vietnam. All three species
   are assigned to the Simulium feuerborni species-group of Simulium
   (Nevermannia). Simulium (N.) langbiangense sp. nov. is characterized by
   the female sensory vesicle with a large opening, and a short common
   basal stalk of the six pupal gill filaments, S. (N.) phami sp. nov. is
   most striking in having the pupal gill with five filaments, a character
   not reported in species of the S. feuerborni species-group, and S. (N.)
   bachmaense sp. nov. is characterized by the female genital fork with a
   triangular lobe-like projection pointed posteromedially on each arm, and
   the small larval postgenal cleft. This represents the first record of
   the S. feuerborni species-group from Vietnam.
C1 Takaoka, Hiroyuki; Univ Malaya, Fac Sci, Kuala Lumpur, 50603, Malaysia,
   Malaysia.
EM takaoka@oita-u.ac.jp

   Zubaidah/R-4012-2019; Ya'cob, Zubaidah/L-7021-2017; Takaoka,
   Hiroyuki/G-6120-2010
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Simulium (Nevermannia) bachmaense; Simulium (Nevermannia) langbiangense;

DT Article
TI A new species of Sybistroma Meigen (Diptera: Dolichopodidae) from the
   Middle East with a key to West-Palaearctic species of the genus.
AU Grichanov, Igor Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
   Kazerani, Farzaneh
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 572-582
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species, Sybistroma occidasiatica sp. nov., from the Middle East
   is described. It is close to S. inornata (Loew, 1857), but is
   distinguished by its long arista-like antennal stylus (longer than
   postpedicel) and short apicoventral epandrial lobe of the hypopygium
   (much shorter than cercus). The new species is peculiar in comprising
   two phenotypes, which can be distinguished by the length ratio of 1st
   and 2nd articles of the antennal stylus. The following recombination is
   also proposed: Sybistroma Caudata (Loew, 1859), comb. nov. (transferred
   from Gymnopternus Loew, 1857). A checklist of the 26 West-Palaearctic
   species of the genus is compiled, as well as a key based mainly on male
   secondary sexual characters. The known distribution of Sybistroma
   Meigen, 1824, is discussed.

DT Article
TI Stalk-eyed wasps-review of a largely unnoticed group of morphologically
   bizarre chalcidoid wasps (Hymenoptera: Eurytomidae: Axima).
AU Arias-Penna, Diana Carolina (ariaspe1@life.illinois.edu) 
   Pape, Thomas
   Krogmann, Lars
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 583-590
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Axima Walker is a small genus of Eurytomidae (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea)
   exclusive to the Western Hemisphere. Some species are distinctive in
   having stalked eyes and Axima sidi, sp. n. is described as the third
   stalk-eyed species based on a single female from Colombia. A key to
   facilitate species identification of stalk-eyed Axima is included. The
   only species of Axima for which host biology is known is a primary
   parasitoid of dwarf carpenter bees of the genus Ceratina Latreille
   (Apidae: Xylocopinae). A hypothesis about the possible function of
   stalked eyes in Axima as devices to assist the escape of adult wasps
   from hosts enclosed in the soft pith of plant stems is proposed.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Apobaetis Day, 1955 (Ephemeroptera: Baetidae) from
   Brazil.
AU Cruz, Paulo Vilela (pvilelacruz@gmail.com) 
   De-Souza, Marcia Regina
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 4
PS 591-599
PD Sep 25 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Apobaetis Day, 1955 species are known for their small size and
   preference for sandy stream substrate. Species which possess such
   habitat preference commonly possess long and slender legs and claws,
   but, in Apobaetis, the length of the tarsal claw rarely is so long that
   it exceeds the length of tarsus, occurring only in two species: A.
   lakota McCafferty, 2000 from USA and A. hamadae Cruz, Boldrini & Salles,
   2011 from Brazil. In the present study, two new species with tarsal
   claws that exceed the length of the tarsi are described: Apobaetis
   pucupi sp. nov. from southeast Brazil and Apobaetis kethepiali sp. nov.
   from northernmost Brazil. Additionally, a new key for nymphs of
   Apobaetis is proposed.
C1 Cruz, Paulo Vilela; Inst Nacl Pesquisas Amazonia, Programa Posgrad
   Entomol, Manaus, Amazonas, BR-69060001 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM pvilelacruz@gmail.com
RI Cruz, Paulo Vilela/I-3070-2016
OI Cruz, Paulo Vilela/0000-0003-2426-4628

   Neotropical region; South America

TI New records of Pauropoda (Myriapoda) with descriptions of new taxa.
AU Scheller, Ulf (ulf.scheller@telia.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 3
PS 301-332
PD Sep 24 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Nine species new to science are described, five species in Pauropodidae:
   Allopauropus circulus n. sp. from France, Decapauropus extremus n. sp.
   from Mexico, D. pyriformis n. sp. from Italy, Stylopauropus laminatus n.
   sp. from Thailand, S. longus n. sp. from Siberia; one in
   Brachypauropodidae: Mojingapauropus biappendiculatus n. gen., n. sp.
   from Panama; one species in Eurypauropodidae Trachypauropus lusitanicus
   n. sp. from Portugal; and two species in Sphaeropauropodidae:
   Sphaeropauropus exilis n. sp. from Papua New Guinea and S. rotatilis n.
   sp. from China. Pauropoda are reported for the first time from New
   Guinea. New collecting sites are given for 69 species.

DT Article
TI A new species of Andinobates (Amphibia: Anura: Dendrobatidae) from west
   central Panama.
AU Batista, Abel (abelbatista@hotmail.com) 
   Jaramillo A., Cesar A.
   Ponce, Marcos
   Crawford, Andrew J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3866
IS 3
PS 333-352
PD Sep 24 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 23
AB Dendrobatid frogs are among the best known anurans in the world, mainly
   due to their toxicity and associated bright colors. A recently described
   dendrobatid genus, Andinobates, comprises frogs distributed among the
   Colombian Andes and Panama. During field work in the Distrito de Donoso,
   Colon province, Panama, we found a poison frog that we here describe as
   a new species. The new species belongs to the A. minutus species group
   and is described herein as Andinobates geminisae sp. nov. This new
   species differs from all other members of the group by having uniformly
   orange smooth skin over the entire body and a distinctive male
   advertisement call. The new species is smaller than other colorful
   dendrobatids present in the area, such as Oophaga pumilio and O.
   vicentei. We also provide molecular phylogenetic analyses of
   mitochondrial DNA sequences of dendrobatids and summarize genetic
   distances among Andinobates species. Andinobates geminisae occurs in
   Caribbean versant rainforest on the westernmost edge of the known
   distribution of A. minutus, and represents the fourth species within
   this genus in Panama. This is vulnerable to habitat loss and excessive
   harvesting and requires immediate conservation plans to preserve this
   species with a restricted geographic range.
C1 Batista, Abel; Univ Autonoma Chiriqui, David, Panama, Panama.
EM abelbatista@hotmail.com
